Fans of the Final Fantasy series, people with attention spans, and those willing to pay $20 for an app will most likely enjoy this game. Classic story, great character customization, solid gameplay, and a familiar feel. I was disappointed at first with the 2D graphics, but they're actually quite attractive and compliment the game well. The music is fantastically scored, although there aren't many unique tracks. The game will take you over 40 hours to complete... thanks to the excessive dungeon crawling and random encounters. It seems like there's a dungeon crawl between every cut scene - and in these dungeons, you'll be in a random encounter every three seconds or so. Sometimes you'll take a step after finishing a battle and find yourself in another one. And with 5 or so unique enemies per dungeon, this game can be really repetitive at times. However, if you can pace yourself and break the monotony, you'll find this game to be a very rewarding experience.

Like FFXIII the game forces control from you and changes the characters you play as. At first it was interesting, but it just got annoying. After playing for hours to progress one group of characters I'm suddenly forced to play with a whole other party because of the way the story is set up. I think the episodic nature of the game just doesn't translate well when the whole game is put together as a whole.  Honestly, if you get to choose between this and any other Final Fantasy title on the market (aside from All the Bravest of course) pick the other title. I bought the game when it was on sale for 50% off, though if you can afford it I would argue the value is still there at full price.  The story is simple but doesn't feel lazy.  The dialogue is nothing to write home about, but the story moves along at a pace that keeps you wanting more.  The game's difficulty is challenging enough to keep you on your toes during boss fights, but is never frustrating.  A messed up difficulty curve could have ruined this game, so I feel they nailed this aspect.  The Job system from FFIII and FFV returns and gives room for loads of customization and flexibility.
